   385â†’## Common Failure Modes & How to Avoid
   386â†’
   387â†’### Failure Mode 1: "I Don't Know What to Do Next"
   388â†’**Symptom:** Finished a phase, not sure who to hand off to
   389â†’**Fix:** Check the phase diagram at top â†’ See next phase owner â†’ Update SYNC.md with handoff
   390â†’
   391â†’### Failure Mode 2: "I'm Stuck and Wasting Time"
   392â†’**Symptom:** Been stuck >1 hour, haven't asked for help
   393â†’**Fix:**
   394â†’1. Try Rafael first (ask specific question with error/context)
   395â†’2. Still stuck after 30 min? â†’ Telegram NLR
   396â†’3. Urgent? â†’ Call NLR
   397â†’
   398â†’### Failure Mode 3: "Client Changed Requirements Mid-Mission"
   399â†’**Symptom:** Client wants something different from AC.md
   400â†’**Fix:**
   401â†’1. Team member handling client decides: is this Swap (equal/lower complexity, â‚¬0) or Add (new milestone, priced)?
   402â†’2. If Swap: Update AC.md, continue
   403â†’3. If Add: Create new milestone, get client approval, schedule separately
   404â†’4. If unsure which: Telegram NLR
   405â†’
   406â†’### Failure Mode 4: "QA Found Critical Bug Right Before Delivery"
   407â†’**Symptom:** Bug breaks core functionality, delivery is tomorrow
   408â†’**Fix:**
   409â†’1. QA team member talks to builder immediately (don't wait)
   410â†’2. Builder asks Rafael for fix
   411â†’3. If fixable in <2 hours: fix, re-test, deliver
   412â†’4. If not fixable quickly: Telegram NLR + postpone delivery 1 day

   559â†’**Scenario 1:** You're Team member. You deployed the app but get a weird error you've never seen. You've been stuck for 45 minutes. What do you do?

   562â†’<summary>Show Answer</summary>

   564â†’**Correct action:**
   565â†’1. Ask Rafael with specific context: "Rafael, I'm getting this error: [paste error]. I tried [X and Y]. What should I do?"
   566â†’2. If Rafael's solution doesn't work after 30 min â†’ Telegram NLR with: error, what you tried, Rafael's suggestion

1â†’# Compensation Structure: The More You Work, The More You Earn
     2â†’
     3â†’**Target audience:** Team members joining ScopeLock
     4â†’**Reading time:** 12 minutes
     5â†’**Prerequisites:** None (Week 1 critical path)
     6â†’
     7â†’**ğŸ“Š Interactive calculator:** [scopelock.mindprotocol.ai/resources/compensation-structure](https://scopelock.mindprotocol.ai/resources/compensation-structure)
     8â†’
     9â†’---
    10â†’
    11â†’## Why This Is Cool
    12â†’
    13â†’**The more you work, the more you earn. And you know exactly how much.**
    14â†’
    15â†’Most agencies pay fixed salaries or hourly rates. You work hard on a project, but your teammate slacks offâ€”you both get paid the same. That's not fair.
    16â†’
    17â†’**ScopeLock is different:**
    18â†’- Every time you send a message to an AI (Rafael, Inna, Sofia, Emma) from Mission Deck, you earn +1 interaction point
    19â†’- Your share of the job: `(Your interactions / Total team interactions) Ã— 30% of job value`
    20â†’- **Real-time visibility:** You see your potential earnings update live as you work
    21â†’- **100% fair:** More contribution = more money. Less contribution = less money.
    22â†’
    23â†’**Example:**
    24â†’```
    25â†’Upwork Job: $1,000
    26â†’Team pool: $300 (30%)
    27â†’
    28â†’You: 20 interactions
    29â†’Teammate: 10 interactions
    30â†’Total: 30 interactions
    31â†’
    32â†’Your earnings: (20/30) Ã— $300 = $200
    33â†’Teammate earnings: (10/30) Ã— $300 = $100
    34â†’
    35â†’You worked 2x as hard â†’ you earn 2x as much. Fair.
    36â†’```
    37â†’
    38â†’---
    39â†’
    40â†’## Why This Matters
    41â†’
    42â†’**"How much will I make if I contribute to 10 missions this month?"**
    43â†’
    44â†’It depends on how much you contribute. If you're very active (lots of messages to AIs), you'll earn more than someone who contributes less. This guide explains exactly how the new system works.
    45â†’
    46â†’**Our philosophy:** Fair compensation means rewarding actual contribution, not arbitrary roles. Work more â†’ earn more. Work less â†’ earn less. Everyone sees everyone's contribution in real-time. No surprises, no politics, no favoritism.
    47â†’
    48â†’---
    49â†’
    50â†’## The New System: Per-Interaction Compensation
    51â†’
    52â†’### How It Works
    53â†’
    54â†’**Step 1:** Every message you send to an AI from Mission Deck earns you +1 interaction point for that job.
    55â†’
    56â†’**Step 2:** When the job completes and the client pays, the 30% team pool is split based on interaction counts:
    57â†’
    58â†’```
    59â†’Your share = (Your interactions / Total team interactions) Ã— 30% of job value
    60â†’```
    61â†’
    62â†’**Step 3:** You get paid when we receive money from the client (typically 21 days after delivery).
    63â†’
    64â†’### What Counts as an Interaction
    65â†’
    66â†’âœ… **Counts:**
    67â†’- Sending a message to Rafael (code generation requests)
    68â†’- Sending a message to Inna (specification questions)
    69â†’- Sending a message to Sofia (QA requests)
    70â†’- Sending a message to Emma (proposal assistance)
    71â†’
    72â†’âŒ **Does NOT count (for now):**
    73â†’- File uploads
    74â†’- Deployments
    75â†’- Testing actions
    76â†’- Messages outside Mission Deck
    77â†’
    78â†’---
    79â†’

    90â†’- Teammate B: 15 messages to AIs
    91â†’- Total: 45 interactions
    92â†’
    93â†’**Earnings:**
    94â†’- You: (15/45) Ã— $300 = **$100**
    95â†’- Teammate A: (15/45) Ã— $300 = **$100**
    96â†’- Teammate B: (15/45) Ã— $300 = **$100**
    97â†’
    98â†’Everyone contributed equally â†’ everyone earns equally.

   135â†’
   136â†’## Missions: Fixed-Price Internal Work
   137â†’
   138â†’Not all work is tied to Upwork jobs. Some work is internal (proposals, recruitment, social posts). These are called **Missions** and have fixed prices:
   139â†’
   140â†’### Mission Pricing
   141â†’
   142â†’- **Write Upwork proposal:** $1 per proposal
   143â†’- **Recruit new team member:** $10 per successful hire
   144â†’- **Post about ScopeLock on X:** $2 per post
   145â†’
   146â†’**How missions are funded:** 5% of every job's value goes into a "mission fund" that pays for these internal tasks.

   156â†’- 10 X posts ($20)
   157â†’Total spent: $35
   158â†’Remaining: $15 (rolls over to next job)
   159â†’```

   348â†’## Key Takeaways
   349â†’
   350â†’### ğŸ’° Fair distribution = motivated team
   351â†’Work more â†’ earn more. Work less â†’ earn less. No politics.
   352â†’
   353â†’### âš¡ Real-time visibility = no surprises
   354â†’You always know exactly what you'll earn before the job completes.
   355â†’
   356â†’### âœ… Quality gates protect everyone
   357â†’Sofia catches bugs before client sees them. Better for reputation and earnings.
   358â†’
   359â†’### ğŸŒ PPP advantage is massive
   360â†’Your earnings go 5-10x further than nominal $ suggests (especially in Nigeria/Colombia).
   361â†’
   362â†’### ğŸ“ˆ Growth path is clear
   363â†’Contribute more â†’ earn more â†’ build reputation â†’ handle bigger jobs â†’ earn even more.
   364â†’

   366â†’
   367â†’## FAQ
   368â†’
   369â†’### Q: What if I'm slower than my teammates? Will I earn less?
   370â†’
   371â†’**A:** Yes, if you contribute fewer interactions, you'll earn less from that job. **But that's fair.** The system rewards contribution, not speed alone. If you're slower but thorough, you might contribute more interactions (asking clarifying questions, requesting more tests, etc.) and still earn a good share.
   372â†’
   373â†’### Q: What if someone spams messages to AIs just to get more interactions?
   374â†’
   375â†’**A:** Sofia (QA) catches low-quality work before delivery. If your interactions don't contribute to the final quality, the job fails â†’ everyone gets $0. You have a strong incentive to make quality contributions, not spam.
   376â†’
   377â†’### Q: Can I see how much my teammates are earning?
   378â†’
   379â†’**A:** Yes. Mission Deck shows everyone's interaction counts and earnings for each job. **This is deliberate.** Transparency prevents resentment and politics. Everyone knows exactly where they stand.
   380â†’
   381â†’### Q: What if I disagree with my interaction count?
   382â†’
   383â†’**A:** All interactions are automatically tracked by Mission Deck (blockchain-verifiable). There's no subjective judgment. If the system didn't count a message, it's because it wasn't sent from Mission Deck to an AI.
   384â†’
   385â†’### Q: What about other work (deployments, testing, debugging)?
   386â†’
   387â†’**A:** For now, only messages to AIs count. We chose this because it's objective, automated, and captures most of the work. As the system matures, we may add other interaction types (deployments, test runs, etc.) if they can be tracked automatically.

messages.content:
I'll analyze the coherence between the markdown documentation and TSX implementations for both files.

## Analysis Results

### 1. **Complete Mission Flow** 
**Markdown:** `/docs/resources/complete-mission-flow.md`  
**TSX:** `/src/app/resources/complete-mission-flow/page.tsx`

**Coherence Status: âš ï¸ PARTIALLY COHERENT**

**What matches well:**
- âœ… 5 phases structure (ACQUIRE, SPECIFY, BUILD, TEST, DELIVER)
- âœ… Phase owners (Bigbosexf, Reanance, Kara) and AI support (Emma, Inna, Rafael, Sofia, Maya, Alexis)
- âœ… Duration estimates (~2 min, TBD, 2-5 days, 2-4 hours, ~1 day)
- âœ… Decision Points Reference table ("Who do I ask?")
- âœ… Quiz section with 3 scenarios
- âœ… Bug fix loop diagram
- âœ… Escalation rules

**Missing from TSX (exists in markdown):**
- âŒ **Day-in-the-Life Example** (full $500 landing page walkthrough from Day 1-11)
- âŒ **Visual Swimlane Diagram** (ASCII timeline showing who does what)
- âŒ **Handoff Checklists** (5 detailed checklists for phase transitions)
- âŒ **Common Failure Modes & How to Avoid** (4 failure scenarios with fixes)
- âŒ **SYNC.md Update Triggers** (when to update SYNC.md)

---

### 2. **Compensation Structure**
**Markdown:** `/docs/resources/compensation-structure.md`  
**TSX:** `/src/app/resources/compensation-structure/page.tsx`

**Coherence Status: âš ï¸ PARTIALLY COHERENT**

**What matches well:**
- âœ… Core concept (per-interaction compensation)
- âœ… Formula: `(Your interactions / Total) Ã— 30%`
- âœ… Example 1 (equal contribution) and Example 2 (you work harder)
- âœ… Commission breakdown (30% team, 5% mission, 10% Upwork fees, etc.)
- âœ… Payment timeline (Day 0 â†’ Day 7 â†’ Day 21)
- âœ… Payment method (Solana/SOL)
- âœ… Quality gates (Sofia bugs, client rejection, job failure)
- âœ… Key takeaways (5 points)
- âœ… Interactive calculator in TSX (bonus feature)

**Missing from TSX (exists in markdown):**
- âŒ **"What Counts as an Interaction"** section (detailed âœ…/âŒ list)
- âŒ **Example 3: Multiple Jobs Per Month** ($10k total revenue example)
- âŒ **Missions: Fixed-Price Internal Work** (detailed mission pricing: $1 proposal, $10 recruitment, $2 post)
- âŒ **Total Compensation Breakdown Per Job** (visual breakdown of $1000 job)
- âŒ **Mission Deck: Real-Time Earnings Display** (ASCII mockups of UI panels)
- âŒ **Real-World Math section** (Nigeria/Colombia purchasing power examples with â‚¦2,013,000/month)
- âŒ **Transparency & Tracking** (Job #47 payment breakdown example)
- âŒ **FAQ section** (4 questions: slower teammate, spamming messages, teammate earnings visibility, disagreeing with count)

---

## Summary

Both TSX implementations are **partially coherent** with their markdown versions:

**Strengths:**
- Core concepts and main examples match well
- TSX adds valuable interactive features (calculator, expandable sections, currency converter)
- Visual hierarchy is consistent

**Issues:**
- **Significant content gaps:** TSX is missing ~40% of markdown content
- **No clear "source of truth":** Are these supplementary views or replacements?
- **Onboarding risk:** New team members may miss critical info if they only read TSX version

**Recommendation:**

You have three options:

1. **Full parity:** Add missing markdown content to TSX (makes TSX comprehensive but longer)
2. **Streamline markdown:** Remove sections from markdown that aren't in TSX (makes markdown match TSX)
3. **Documented divergence:** Keep them different but add a note explaining "TSX = visual overview, Markdown = complete reference"

Which approach would you prefer? I can help implement any of these.
